[149][Beat] We will.

[158]You may have known my father, William Starks.

[160]Did you know my father?

[169]I don't know. 
[170]How far away is that? 
[171]I know. It was perfect. [Beat] Erase my sanity and you erase anything I'll ever say. Well, doesn't what he did to you make you mad?

[173]I might not be able to. 
[174]I'll die either way.

[178]This has nothing to do with that. Then what? What? [Beat] I can't guess it. You have to help me. 
[179]...What you do not know is the only thing you know. 
[180][Beat] And what you own is what you do not own... And where you are is where you are not. 
[181]I don't know. [Frustrated] Remember? 
[182][Beat] I've seen a time that's not this time. And I'm only able to see it when I'm in the Jacket.

So really, what was the point? Torture? I think that's still sort of illegal in some states -- though we'll have to check on Vermont. And, how's this for the cherry on top: it seems my physician is a pill-popping freak. [Beat] Last time I checked, that makes some pretty good copy for a lot of these news shows. [Humbly, deftly] "I don't remember everything they did to me. I just remember the worst parts." I think I should be sitting down when I say it, don't you think?

[297]I think so.

[299]You work there? Yeah, I'm a nurse. Why don't you let me give you a ride... 
[300]Thanks. 
[301]Nothin' to worry about there. 
[302]I'm doing fine.

[76]William! William! 
[77]Maybe he's gone somewhere. He'll have to come back. 
[78]It's Sunday. 
[79]So? 
[80]William, you're not making sense. 
[81]That's all you got from him? That bastard helped take your life away from you. 
[82]What? How can you say that? He's the one that put you in that goddamn medieval...Jacket. He's probably the one who killed you. 
[83]Why are you saying that? [Beat] We don't have long, do we? 
[84]To the hospital. 
[85]Claire, I need help. 
[86]Because your body can only take so much of what they're putting you through. 
[87]Ok. Ssh. Rest. 
[88]No! It won't do any good. [Beat] Please, Claire. They won't understand. 
[89]William, please, honey, wake up. For me. 
[90]Can you hear me? 
[91]I found out about Eugene. The little boy. He's the key. That's who you have to tell her about when you get back there. It's the only way to prove this to her. 
[92]What? 
[93]112 Orchard Way. [Realizing, in a whisper] You're not coming back, are you? 
[94]Then, where are you going? 
[95]I've been ok. 
[96]Ok, I guess. 
[97]Sure. 
[98]Mom, this is the guy that drove us home that afternoon we were stuck on the highway. The guy you yelled at for no good reason... 
[99]Why? 
[100]Hey, wait! 
[101]Ok. 
[102]Hey there. [Beat] You ok? 
[103]You're bleeding pretty bad there. 
[104]It's ok. It's ok. Relax. It's just a cut. We can get it fixed. 
[105]But we need to get you to the hospital now. How'd you get that? 
[106]Sorry, one sec. 
[107]Hey! How are you? [Beat] Thanks. I was just thinking about you, too. 
[108]Listen, I gotta go, mom, 'cause I'm late... but, thanks. Happy New Year to you, too. I'll call you later. [Beat] Ok, bye. 
[109]Sorry about that. It was my mom. 
[110]How you doin'?
dialogues.LORENSON:
[1]Where's William Starks. 
[2]Are you kidding me? He's not psychotic! 
[3]He'll be a zombie in a few days, Tom. His behavior's hardly suggested he needed neuroleptics. 
[4][Beat] You sure he wasn't provoked? 
[5]I'm sure he took some, too. Happens sometimes when you've got to restrain them. You watch the rest of us work. You know that. Our patients are sick. 
[6]He's not gonna end up like Casey, Tom. Whatever happened to him is not going to "happen" to Starks. I don't know what you're trying to do here ...but he's not a lab animal, Tom. You can't reprogram him no matter the drugs or the treatment. 
[7]Hey. You're not supposed to be out here. What are you going to do to me? 
[8]Well... I thought I'd just ask you to come back inside with me. 
[9]I guess I'd ask you why. 
[10]You're not crazy. 
[11]You suffer from delusional disorder. That doesn't mean you're... crazy. It just means you're confused. And you're here, instead of in jail, because that was determined to have played a role in your killing of a police officer. Alleged killing of a police officer. 
[12]You were convicted of the crime. 
[13]You may never remember at all. [Beat] Your mind's grasp of reality and the real events that have happened to you has been damaged. 
[14][Beat] William, I'd like to ask you something if I can. 
[15]I could try to...make it stop. 
[16]So it's helping? [Beat] It's making me feel like a different person. 
[17]You should be careful. You could be killed if they found you out here. 
[18]I wish they'd skip the formality of this annual review and just cut our budget. Our silence on the matter should be enough to appease the civic conscience without wasting an hour we don't have. 
[19]It's the ticking of a box on a sheet of paper no one cares about. 
[20]What should they be looking for? 
[21]Where? [Beat] It's Becker isn't it? He's doing stuff, isn't he? 
[22]Hello. I'm Beth Lorenson. 
[23]It's nice to meet you, Mr. Starks... 
[24]And you are...? 
[25]I think we'll be fine from here. Thanks, Stanley. 
[26]My God you look exactly like him. 
[27]Yeah, I did. [Beat] He was my most memorable patient. 
[28]At the end, he made me change my mind about a lot of things. 
[29]No. I don't think he was crazy. He needed help...but he wasn't crazy. [Beat] Your father actually helped me with a case of mine. 
[30]I was working with a boy named Eugene. 
[31]It's complicated, but [looking at Starks] in a way, your father let me know how I'd get through to him. 
[32]He just said...that I'd shock Eugene and then things would change for him. 
[33]I still don't either, even after all these years. 
[34][Beat] I don't know. 
[35]I was. But I saw a lot of cuts and a lot of blows. I'm sorry I don't know more about your father's. [Sincerely] I didn't know about everything that went on here. 
[36]How do you know about Dr. Becker? 
[37]That's right. He did. 
[38]So maybe Dr. Becker would know. [Beat] But, as I'm sure you know, the statute of limitations has run out for charging the hospital with any liabilities. 
[39]I see you've done your homework. [Beat] Alpine Grove's undergone a lot of changes since then. At the time, we didn't have the...resources to help our patients the way we needed to. [Beat] Now, we do. And things are different. 
[40]It's important for you to know who your father was, isn't it? 
[41]Well... [beat] let me know how your search turns out. 
[42]You'll die if you keep smoking those in your condition. 
[43]I can't try to help you unless you let me. [Beat] I know about the Jacket. 
[44]I'm sorry for what you were put through, and I'm sorry I couldn't stop it earlier. But I promise you that I will from now on... 
[45]What do you mean? 
[46]No, I do. That's what I'm saying to you. 
[47]How can you say that in your physical condition? Do you realize that it's because you were put in it that you're as...weak as you are now? Becker's a man who's not well himself. 
[48]Then help me understand. You know, you're not alone. A lot of Gulf Vets have begun to experience curious symptoms. What you have might well be a syndrome and, if so, it's not one we know enough about to be treating it this vigorously. 
[49][Beat] Where is that from? 
[50]Come on. Tell me what you do know. 
[51]Well, what time is it? 
[52]Ok fine. Tell me about it. Tell me about the future. 2004. What does it look like? 
[53]The future doesn't look different? 
[54]What about the world? 
[55]Do you think you're traveling in time? Is that it? 
[56][Beat] Like who? Like MacKenzie maybe? 
[57]MacKenzie locked himself up in his house for two months and nearly starved himself to death before he was brought here. All because his wife left him for another man. 
[58]Why don't you help me? 
[59]Why not? 
[60]And how do you know that? 
[61]William, that is just another facet of my delusions. 
[62]How do you know about Eugene? 
[63]There obviously is, so what don't you just tell me how you found out about him. 
[64]I don't know how you know about Eugene, but these ideas are part of your delusions. 
[65]One thing's got nothing to do with the other. 
[66]Nina, William Starks is to stay in ICU all night. If anything is supposed to change, I want to be called about it. 
[67]Hi. [Beat] Sorry I'm late. 
[68]Talia, I need to ask you something. 
[69]Have you told anyone about my sessions with Eugene? Of course not. [Off Lorenson's still doubtful look] I swear I haven't. I wouldn't do that to Eugene, or you. You know that. 
[70]Has anyone been asking about him? 
[71]Eugene, this is a "TRAIN." 
[72]Come on back down here. Wherever you are...try to come on back. You'll like it, I promise. 
[73]I know. I know it all. Save your strength. I already know everything you're going to say. [Beat] You're in the Jacket right now, aren't you? 
[74]You told me this was how it happened. 
[75]Yeah. 
[76]You have nothing to fear, William. 
[77]A cup of coffee would be great, Sally. Thanks. 
[78]I hope so. 
[79]You're going to be ok, William. We just need to get your fever down and we'll be able to hopefully stabilize you. 
[80]What for? 
[81]I'm not gonna let that happen. 
[82]I do believe you... 
[83]William, I can't indulge these delusions, even when you're in this state. 
[84]Who told you this? 
[85]What are you talking about? 
[86]Hey. 
[87]Come on Eugene, try to say it with me. This is a "DOG". 
[88]Are you having a seizure? Is that really what's going on? 
[89]You ok, Eugene? 
[90]No, but he is having seizures. 
[91]Sure. It's an easy address. A little far out there, but easy enough. 
[92]You want me to come with you?
dialogues.BECKER:
[1]William? William, can you hear me? 
[2]I've given you some drugs to help with your adjustment... 
[3]Well, your condition's pretty serious. 
[4]I'm just looking at you. Does that make you uncomfortable? 
[5]You said you couldn't remember killing Officer Harrison. Correct? 
[6]It's not my job to believe you. You're a doctor. I would think... It's not my job to believe you or to understand you. It's my job to try to cure you and if that's a no-go, then to...take some kind of care of you. Lucky me. You shot a man three times: first in his heart, then in his stomach and then...point blank, in the back of his head. And then you just...forgot all about it. A whole life erased with three easy little words: I. Don't. Know. What would it be if we could all not know what we didn't want to have to face. 
[7]It's ok, Harold. It's ok. I don't belong here... Get him to his room. 
[8]No. I don't think you do either. [Beat] But neither of us can do anything about that. 
[9]Take him out of it. 
[10]William. William, can you hear me? Pulse is 16, temp, just a hair under 90. 'Bout right for three hours of psychosis. 
[11]I'm glad to see you're cooperating this time, Mr. Starks. 
[12]No. That's not necessary. 
[13]Let him go. [More firmly] I said, let him go! 
[14]The only thing your mind is missing is a conscience. 
[15]I'm fine. 
[16]Then don't. 
[17]What about Starks? 
[18]Should we be what? Trying to change him any way we can? [Beat] Yes. 
[19][Beat] It's Christmas Eve, Justin. Don't you have somewhere to be? 
[20]You left him in all night? 
[21]Don't get all worked up, Justin. I expected some common sense on your part and clearly I was expecting too much. [Beat] Just open the drawer. 
[22]Well, what are we gonna do about it now? 
[23]No. [To Harding and Damon] Get him upstairs. 
[24]He's recovering on the third floor. 
[25]Then how would you describe him, Beth? Merely rebellious? 
[26]And you know that from what, a couple two-minute stares across a room? He didn't need anti-psychotics, if that's even all you're giving him...? 
[27]You sure you want to begin making that kind of insinuation? [Beat] I took five stitches during a routine therapy session. 
[28]Yes, they are. 
[29]Jesus, you really don't let up, do you? Just because you failed your patient doesn't necessarily mean the rest of us did, too. [Beat] Sorry to tarnish your war hero's image, but he is psychotic. 
[30]Now, if you'll excuse me, it's Christmas, and I have a family I'd like to see. 
[31]I said the drugs were to help you sleep. [Beat] Did you sleep well? But I wasn't asleep. Was I? 
[32]Yes. You were. You were asleep for nearly a whole day. It's December 26th, William. 
[33]That's right, William. 1992? 
[34]Yes. [Caustically] And that's the sun and you're on earth. [Beat] And I know you know better. 
[35]In where? 
[36]We were forced to use restrains if that's what you're referring to. 
[37]Actually, that's exactly what our equipment is. 
[38]Relax. 
[39][Pointedly] Of course you're not. 
[40]You're just suffering from delusions that are unfortunately part of your condition. 
[41]I had a patient a few years ago. His name was Ted Casey... 
[42]I wasn't pausing to see if you did. [Beat] But, incidentally, you should, because you're birds of a feather. 
[43]Ted raped and sodomized a seven-year old girl. [Beat] His lawyers asked me to have a look at him because, after his deeds were done... he climbed into the trees of the forest where he killed her and woofed like a dog. He couldn't even remember his name when I spoke to him, but, curiously enough, he could speak back. [Beat] Ted never went to prison because everyone -- including me -- was convinced he was sick. So he came here. 
[44]Then one day a little girl came with her mother to visit a relative and I caught Ted stealing looks at her -- the kind you really have to steal if you know what I mean. [Beat] I asked Ted then if he could remember what the little girl who he had... slain ...was wearing. [Beat] He gave me a look I'll never forget, and, when he answered, it wasn't with a color or any sort of physical description I'd expect. "Oh yes," he said. "I remember it. I remember it well." [Beat] Those were actually his last words I think. 
[45]Maybe not. [Beat] But I do think you're in a tree... woofing like a dog. And I'm just trying to help you the only way I can think of. What happened to your cheek, Dr. Becker? 
[46]I was careless. Happens sometimes. 
[47]Mr. Starks, this session is for our civil patients. Damon, please take Mr. Starks back to his ward. No. Please, Dr. Becker. You can strap me in a Jacket or even gag me, but please don't leave me out of therapy. This is where I feel like I make the most progress. 
[48]Fine, Mr. Starks. You can pull up a chair for yourself. 
[49]Mr. Jensen, please continue. 
[50]The Organization...for the Organized? 
[51]No, Mr. Jensen. I have not. 
[52]And how is that? 
[53]Sit down, Mr. Starks! Sit down, Mr. Starks! 
[54]Sit down, Mr. Jensen! 
[55]At least it's some kind of bars we've got you behind. 
[56]Hello, William. I understand you've been asking for me almost every hour. I would've been here sooner but you gave our little state visitor quite a bit to talk to me about. 
[57]It is. But when it comes down to it, you just have to patient with them. They'd rather have their vacation, too, so they just push dealing with our "practices" off to the New Year. 
[58]Temporarily. 
[59]And what's that? 
[60]Yes. 
[61]You killed him? 
[62]I think...I have to think about it. 
[63]I think your story needs a little fleshing out before it's ready to go. 
[64]I'll say a prayer for you in Church today, Starks. Maybe the Gods can pick up where the medicine left off. 
[65]I've managed to every Sunday of my life. [Beat] Some of us are God- fearing men, Starks. 
[66]Means we believe in doing his work and fear what the world would be like if we didn't at least try to. 
[67]You in here. [Beat] Works like a drug. 
[68]Who are you? 
[69][Beat] You're his son? 
[70]How...how are you here? 
[71]You died, Starks. Years ago, in the hospital. 
[72]No. I didn't. I swear I didn't. I probably helped push you to kill yourself, but I didn't do it. 
[73]I don't know how you died. The last time I put you in the Jacket was just after you told me you remembered killing that police officer... 
[74]I know. [Beat] I knew that when you came out. 
[75]Because...because you came out and said something you couldn't have possibly have known. You came back and repeated three names... 
[76]Of people like you. People I was just trying to help. They couldn't get worse so I thought, with medication, they might get... 
[77]It was part of the treatment I intended...I didn't know what the effects would be... 
[78]The three of you weren't regular patients. You were criminals that ended up at Alpine Grove. 
[79]You and the others didn't seem that way then. 
[80]What is it? 
[81]How did you come to know their names? 
[82]I don't understand... 
[83]I didn't put you in Alpine Grove.
dialogues.WAITRESS:
[1]Where do you think you're going? 
[2]You gonna answer me? 
[3]If you're deaf, read my lips...I don't need a psycho following me today. 
[4]Good. 
[5][As if she owes him an explanation] I forgot my purse. 
[6]In case you hadn't figured, it's Christmas Eve. You're never gonna get a cab here. 
[7]All right. [Beat] You got somewhere you need to go, Mister? 
[8]Let me ask you that again. This time, look around and consider your options. 
[9][Beat] You got somewhere you need to go, Mister? Yeah, I do. 
[10]Great, get in. 
[11]So, where do you want me to drop you? 
[12]You don't have anywhere to stay? 
[13]Well, where are you from? 
[14]Of course you don't know. 
[15]Because in my life, it wouldn't make sense for me to pick up some normal guy with a place where he's from and a place where he's going to. It'd be too simple. I probably wouldn't know how to handle a situation like that. 
[16]At least you're honest. That's some kind of start. 
[17]That's great. You're not sure where you're from or where you're going, but at least you've got manners. 
[18]Well, you got a coat or something? 
[19]Well, how'd you get here? 
[20]Do you have a motel or something? Money? 
[21]Well, don't you somewhere? Stuff? Belongings? 
[22]All right, we'll get to my place and call around, see where I can take you. [Beat] Just don't think of trying anything. 
[23]I have the biggest defense for gun control living upstairs from me. She's armed and angry even when she's asleep. 
[24]Great. That was our last option. What am I going to do with you? 
[25]Where are you going? You'll freeze out there. You don't even have a coat. 
[26]No, you won't. You'll die of cold out there and then I'll have to feel guilty. And I've already got more guilt than I know what to do with. [Beat] Do you want something to drink? 
[27]Shit! That was one of my good glasses! Hey, you ok? 
[28]You know what? It's Christmas Eve. And you look clean -- I mean, you're normal-looking. [Resolutely, for her own benefit] It's Christmas Eve, and I have a couch. 
[29]What's this? 
[30]No, it's fine. [Beat, swallow] Thanks. 
[31]You want a drink? 
[32]This is pretty good. Considering... 
[33]Yup. That's me. 
[34][Beat] I do it. 
[35]Shit happens, and your life changes. 'Bout the best explanation of a lot of things that happen. [Beat] So how come you don't know where you're coming from? 
[36]Well, good for you. 
[37][Beat] Real is overrated. 
[38]Maybe. [Beat] Maybe not. 
[39]Sometimes I don't know the difference myself. And, you know something? I think I like it better that way. [Finishes her drink] You want another one? 
[40]You remember it? 
[41]May be easy to remember, but not easy to get. Being warm, maybe -- but, look, you don't even have a coat and I still have to chop wood to make a fire. [Beat] And, being happy...you tell me if that's simple. 
[42]So you never knew your mother? 
[43]I'm sorry. 
[44]Never knew my father. I grew up with my mother. Actually, I grew up around my mother. She was great though. I mean, the way she was with her friends... She was this woman who had so much life in her, she had to find ways to kill some of it just to be like the rest of us. [Beat] She died young. 
[45]She fucked herself up day after day and then, one day, she fell asleep with a burning cigarette. [Beat] I came home from work and she was gone. 
[46]Yeah, me too. [Softly] Every day for the last ten years.
dialogues.MACKENZIE:
[1]That's Kingsley. Old bastard hears us, I'm sure. He just doesn't want to bother answering so he makes us think he can't talk. I know. I tried it on my mother for two months once before she fished out my tongue. Literally. [Beat] You're the cop killer, right? 
[2]TV. Helps numb [makes a "crazy gesture"] any active mind. [Sticking out a jittery hand] Rudy MacKenzie. 
[3]Welcome to the village, William Starks. 
[4]That's too bad. I don't believe in disposable language either -- you know, the small talk, the little talk. Chit. Chat. Useless. The game's something else though. Think about it: What can we trade with each other in the air between us? This... [running his hand through the air] is our court. [Beat, so eager it's sad] I'm ready to throw the ball. Come on. What are you in here for? 
[5]I tried to kill my wife. 
[6]I tried something like 30 times. 
[7]She's bigger than me, and she's stronger than me. And I never planned on doing it. It was always in the heat of the moment. I didn't beat her or anything. Hell, she beat me. But when we'd start fighting, I'd go for the knife. Then she kept threatening to have me put away, and [looking around] she finally did. 
[8]Or just plain stupid. You'd think by the twentieth time, I'd have found an alternative method. Maybe a more effective one, if you know what I mean. 
[9]It's a hard one for me, Dr. Lorenson. [Finally turns to face her, grimly] The world around me, it's shrinking. There's not even room for light to make its way in. [Beat] Da-da-bum! Da- da-bum! I feel like the horseman of doom is coming for me, Doc. Only today, he's not carrying flowers. 
[10]What? It's better than fine. 
[11]Of course you can, Doc. William, it was an absolute pleasure. Thanks for playing. 
[12]Hey...when they talk you out to the woods tonight and invite the wolves, dance with them. [Beat] They don't eat you when there's music playing. 
[13]When they take you out to the woods tonight and invite the wolves, dance with them. 
[14]They don't eat you when there's music playing. 
[15]I wasn't talking about anything. 
[16]I know you need one when it's really cold. 
[17]Mortality's actually a great thing to be familiar with. It means you're sane on some level. 
[18][Beat] How do you know? 
[19]Oh no, you're pretty young. Your body'll be able to handle a lot more of it than you think... 
[20]It's gonna be sticky. 
[21]'Cause Lorenson's got her claws in it now. When she started getting suspicious about me was when they stopped using it on me. Women! 
[22]You could still always give Becker an itch. 'Course you might get killed when he goes to scratch it, but seems to me you're saying that's about to happen anyway. [Beat] Just be careful not to walk yourself right into something. 
[23]Hey, I brought you some smokes. 
[24]Geez, how's that for a fucking "thank you"? 
[25]She left me, I tried to kill her, I tried to kill myself. She was mean, I was weak, I was cruel so she left, I didn't plan it, didn't see it...FINE! I didn't want to see it. I'm in here because they say I have a nervous condition. [Beat] Well, here's my question, who wouldn't be nervous if they really looked at their life? [Beat] Whose life is that good? 
[26]Not this luckless little mammal's. What difference is it to them? [Beat, slows down] You believe what you want to believe. One version is easier than another so you make it your own. 
[27]I'll tell you this though. However nuts I am, I wasn't nuts enough not to know how wrong it was to put a human being in something like that. 
[28][Shrugging] What if we are? There're crazier things than thinking up fictions for yourself. [Beat] Everyone does it, don't they? Even Becker. That roller coaster car pops more pills than all of Ward 3. 
[29]I've been here for 11 years. It's my neighborhood. 'Course I'm sure. He's as drugged up as the rest of us...I guess he has to be to put up with all this.
dialogues.DAMON:
[1]I'm sorry, Starks. Must have not seen you coming there. Were you worried about me? [Smiling] That's so sweet. Thanks. 
[2]Fuck the tranquilizer! I got a foot. 
[3]You got any booze? 
[4]Starks, you're like a mule. You're real stubborn. But there's ways of fixin' that. All you need is a good stick. [Beat] Here's your stick. 
[5]You folks ain't supposed to be down here. 
[6]Do I know you from somewhere? 
[7]That's right! Goddamn, you're the spitting image. I didn't know he had a son. 
[8]Oh yeah, sure. He killed a cop, right? 
[9]Oh yeah, what'd he say? 
[10]Look here, I don't like you getting in my face and saying this bullshit to me... 
[11]I thought you said you never knew your father. 
[12]I don't know what you're talking about, man. I swear. This is some weird shit you're telling me... and I don't know how come you're doing it. 
[13]I never touched your father! I swear! 
[14]No funny business or we can make this a lot fucking harder for you.
dialogues.JEAN:
[1]Get your fucking hands off my daughter! 
[2]Jackie, get in the car. NOW! 
[3]Look, I don't want any trouble, so... 
[4]Can I help you? 
[5]I'm sorry? Your face looks awfully familiar, I just can't quite place it... 
[6]Oh, yeah. 
[7]There something you need? 
[8]Jackie, go play in the snow. 
[9]Just do it. 
[10]Thanks. You, too.
dialogues.TENNY:
[1]You ever been to jail? 
[2]It's worse than war. It's worse than anywhere you've ever been. 
[3]Well, I've never been to war, but I'm sure as hell not going back to prison. Recreation. 
[4]Man, if you're so deaf and dumb, you ain't even worth a fucking bullet. 
[5]Hey, Mister, you need a ride? 
[6]I'm going to Canada but I can let you ride with me up to the border. 
[7]Can you drive? 
[8]Great, get in. We'll switch off in a bit.
dialogues.NURSE HARDING:
[1]Come on, army boy. Time for some therapy. 
[2]That's not enough, is it? It's enough for now. Take him to the infirmary and let him recover there. 
[3]You gonna get the fuck up? 
[4]Ah, man, look, It's A Wonderful Life. 
[5]'Course I do. [Smiling] And it is the season for giving so let's get to it. 
[6]Shit, he's probably dead. I tried to ask you if we should leave him in yesterday...
dialogues.TALIA:
[1]It's ok. [To Eugene] Hi, Eugene. 
[2]What is it? 
[3]No. I would have told you. 
[4]What is it? 
[5]What's happening? He got a little shock. [To himself] And it's reset him. Not permanently probably...but at least for a little while. They use it on epileptic patients sometimes... 
[6]But he's not epileptic.
